item.title: Fire in Hermosillo, Mexico, Kills at Least 23 at Waldo’s Store
item.description: The fire ripped through a store in Hermosillo, a city in Sonora State. The governor said 11 others were injured and that minors were among the victims.

item.title: He Stayed in Belarus for His Imprisoned Wife. Now He’s Locked Up, Too.
item.description: Two journalists, both in detention for their work, show how President Aleksandr Lukashenko’s repressive machine grinds on despite warming ties with the U.S.

item.title: Death Toll Rises From Hurricane Melissa as Many Communities Remain Cut off
item.description: Authorities have yet to reach dozens of communities in Jamaica, raising the question of how many people really died in last week’s storm.

item.title: An Outlier in Irish Politics Has Become the Country’s President
item.description: Propelled by anti-establishment fervor, Catherine Connolly was elected last week with a landmark popular mandate.

item.title: See How Thailand’s Pets Become Speed Eating Contest Champions
item.description: Speed eating contests are part of a growing list of pet-related events in Thailand that also include competitions for skateboarding dogs and felines that look like cows.

item.title: Can South Korea Manage the Competing Needs of the U.S. and China?
item.description: The country’s new president rolled out the red carpet for China’s leader, Xi Jinping, and President Trump this week, but the superpower rivalry is making it harder to balance relations.

item.title: 2 Arrested After Stabbing on Train Near Cambridge, England
item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain denounced the attack, which the police said left nine victims with “life-threatening injuries.”

item.title: Trump Threatens Military Action in Nigeria Over Protections for Christians
item.description: Accusing Nigeria of not doing enough to protect Christians from violence, President Trump said he had ordered the Pentagon to prepare for action.

item.title: Air Pollution Could Be Contributing to Your Slower Marathon Time
item.description: Marathon runners consistently finished slower in cities with higher levels of dangerous particles in the air, researchers found.

item.title: After Days of Protests, Tanzania’s President Is Declared Election Winner
item.description: Election monitors and members of the European Parliament have questioned the election’s integrity, and violent protests have rocked the country.

item.title: Two More Suspects Charged in Louvre Heist Case
item.description: In addition to the two main suspects, who partially admitted to the robbery, two others have been charged by the Paris prosecutor overseeing the case.

item.title: Juan Ramón Matta Ballesteros, 80, Dies; Cartel Kingpin Fed Cocaine Boom
item.description: Before being imprisoned in the late 1980s, he made a fortune as a Honduran power broker connecting Colombian and Mexican cartels.

item.title: In One Jamaican Town, Hurricane Melissa Left Behind Floodwaters and Dead Livestock
item.description: The Category 5 storm ravaged western Jamaica and drenched the small community of New River, where residents were coping with a massive clean up. At least 19 people have died nationwide, officials said.

item.title: Putin Brandishes Menacing Nuclear Weapons as Talks With U.S. Falter
item.description: Touting new weapons tests, Moscow signals to Washington that it must contend with the Kremlin’s power and negotiate.

item.title: Quality Time
item.description: Daylight saving time ends tomorrow. The decrease in daylight can be destabilizing — and clarifying.

item.title: Saudi Prince Plans Ambitious U.S. Visit, but Opening Ties With Israel Is Unlikely
item.description: The crown prince of Saudi Arabia is pushing for a security pact and a nuclear deal with the United States yet is not expected to recognize Israel soon, despite President Trump’s wishes.

item.title: Spurned by Trump, Carney Begins Thawing Canada’s China Connection
item.description: The meeting between Prime Minister Mark Carney and Xi Jinping, China’s top leader, came after a long period of tension and estrangement.

item.title: Far Right Targets Similarities Between Zohran Mamdani and Sadiq Khan
item.description: Zohran Mamdani, the leading contender in the Nov. 4 New York election, and Sadiq Khan, London’s mayor, are liberal and Muslim, but they’re navigating varied politics, communities and cities.

item.title: Working Past 100? In Japan, Some People Never Quit.
item.description: We met five remarkable people who’ve lived for more than a century and have yet to retire. For them, a working life is a richer one.

item.title: Carney Says He Apologized to Trump Over Ad Reviving Reagan’s Tariff Criticism
item.description: The Canadian prime minister also said that he had asked the province of Ontario not to air the ad that later prompted the president to end trade talks.

item.title: Twenty Years Later, Atrocities Haunt Darfur Again
item.description: The world seems unable, or unwilling, to do much to stop a new struggle on an old battlefield, as atrocities sweep villages and towns.

item.title: For These Women, the American Dream Is in Mexico City
item.description: Thousands of foreign women have moved to the Mexican capital for a “life reset,” creating successful businesses and drawing more expats like them. Not all Mexicans are pleased.

item.title: He Survived the Invasion. What He Really Wanted Was a Friend.
item.description: During the war, a Ukrainian boy lost his home, his father and his friends. Could he find new buddies at a camp in the mountains?

item.title: Tanzania Racked by Deadly Protests After Election
item.description: The United Nations said at least 10 people had been killed. Opposition leaders claimed the death toll could be in the hundreds, and one official called for the military to step in.

item.title: Ukraine Gamifies the War: 40 Points to Destroy a Tank, 12 to Kill a Soldier
item.description: Drone teams compete to ascend a scoreboard that rewards units for successful attacks. Ukrainian officials say the contest helps keep soldiers motivated.

item.title: What’s Next for Andrew After He Loses ‘Prince’ Title?
item.description: King Charles III’s brother will retreat further from public life after additional damaging revelations about his ties to the sexual predator Jeffrey Epstein.

item.title: Selma van de Perre, Dutch Jew Who Resisted Nazis, Dies at 103
item.description: “It is impossible not to marvel at her steadiness and courage,” one reviewer wrote after reading her memoir.

item.title: Low Prices Aren’t Stopping Exxon and Chevron From Pumping More Oil
item.description: The two biggest U.S. oil companies increased production in the third quarter and reported lower but still robust profits.

item.title: Candy Companies Are Quietly Cutting Down on Cocoa to Save Money
item.description: As climate change has helped push cocoa prices higher, companies are changing candy recipes in subtle ways.

item.title: Will the Unmaking of Prince Andrew Be the Making of King Charles?
item.description: The decision by King Charles III to strip the title of his brother Prince Andrew showed a level of accountability rarely applied to royals.

item.title: U.N. Says Strikes on Boats Trump Claims Are Smuggling Drugs Are Illegal
item.description: The U.N.’s human rights chief condemned deadly military attacks on vessels near South and Central America and called for an independent investigation.

item.title: How Saudi Arabia and Qatar Benefited From Rule Changes to Reach the World Cup
item.description: A soccer governing body that both countries have helped bankroll gave them extra rest and home-field advantage to set up World Cup qualification.

item.title: Jamaica Prepared a Financial Fortress for Disaster. Hurricane Melissa Will Test It.
item.description: All of Jamaica’s financial defenses — insurance, bonds and credit lines — could be deployed to recover from Hurricane Melissa. Will it be enough?

item.title: Xi Delivers Veiled Warning to Nations Not to Take the U.S.’s Side
item.description: At an Asia-Pacific summit, the Chinese leader urged countries to “resist unilateral bullying,” an appeal that seemed at odds with his country’s recent actions.

item.title: Carney Meets With Xi to Try and Reset Relations
item.description: The leaders of Canada and China met for the first time in eight years to try to reset relations after years of acrimony.

item.title: Executions and Mass Casualties: Videos Show Horror Unfolding in Sudan
item.description: Evidence of atrocities emerging from the city of El Fasher stoked fears that the Sudanese region of Darfur is plunging, once again, into a cycle of genocidal violence.

item.title: Some of Trump’s Favorite Things on Asia Trip: A Crown and ‘Vicious’ Weapons
item.description: President Trump traveled to Asia to be a statesman, a showman and a traveling salesman, depending on the audience.

item.title: The Mystery Lady in the Governor’s Palace? Maybe a Ghost, He Says
item.description: When a figure appeared in the window of a government building, the governor suggested she was an empress’s ghost. Months later, people are still talking about it.

item.title: Prince Andrew to Be Stripped of His Royal Title
item.description: The extraordinary move caps his fall from grace over his ties to the convicted sexual predator Jeffrey Epstein.

item.title: How the Trump-Xi Meeting Eased a Major Trade War
item.description: President Trump and China’s leader Xi Jinping just had a highly anticipated meeting in South Korea. David Pierson, a New York Times foreign correspondent covering China, breaks down what they accomplished and how they de-escalated a major trade war.

item.title: Who Walked Away Stronger in U.S.-China Trade Talks?
item.description: Xi Jinping secured concessions from Donald Trump in exchange for returning to the status quo.

item.title: In China Truce on Tariffs and Rare Earths, National Security Controls Are Bargaining Chip
item.description: Some analysts say Beijing won a major victory in its trade talks: Getting the U.S. to withdraw a national security measure that previously was not under discussion.

item.title: U.S. Beef and Thousand Island Dressing: Trump’s Food Tour of Asia
item.description: The menus on the president’s tour of three countries in Asia reflected the culinary acrobatics the host nations performed to accommodate his palate and foreign policy goals.

item.title: How Xi Walked Away From Trump Trade Talks Looking Stronger
item.description: By withholding soybean purchases and rare-earth exports, China extracted relief from U.S. tariffs and delayed export controls, without conceding much in return.

item.title: Inside the Louvre Jewel Heist That Shocked the World
item.description: More than a week after thieves made off with treasures from the Louvre, a picture is emerging of a seemingly well-planned burglary that exploited security lapses at the museum and outpaced the police.

item.title: Trump’s Call to Resume Nuclear Testing After Decades Revives a Cold War Debate
item.description: President Trump explained the order by saying other, unnamed nations were testing their own nuclear weapons, even though no country has tested since 2017.

item.title: What to Know About US Nuclear Weapons as Trump Threatens to Restart Testing
item.description: Though the country’s nuclear arsenal has undergone no explosive testing for decades, federal experts say it can reliably obliterate targets halfway around the globe.

item.title: Israel’s Ultra-Orthodox Stage ‘March of the Million’ Against Military Draft
item.description: Hundreds of thousands took to the streets of Jerusalem on Thursday to protest against efforts to end an exemption from military service for Israel’s Haredi religious students.

item.title: Who Is Driving U.S. Attacks in the Caribbean?
item.description: What’s the main goal of the U.S. military buildup in the Caribbean, and who in the Trump administration is behind it? Anatoly Kurmanaev, a New York Times reporter who covered Venezuela, discusses with Katrin Bennhold what we know and don’t know.

item.title: Six Arrested in Robbery of Precious-Metal Refinery in France
item.description: The robbers used explosives to gain entry to a precious-metal company in Lyon, French officials said. The police recovered the items.

item.title: Wilders’s Far-Right Party Faces Rebuke in the Netherlands
item.description: Geert Wilders suffered a loss of support as a center-left party staged major gains, an election result that could offer lessons for Europe’s far right.

item.title: In Canada, a New Play Celebrates Indigenous Storytelling of the Northern Lights
item.description: The aurora borealis draws thousands of visitors to the Far North each year. A new play tells the lights’ tales from the perspective of Indigenous creators.

item.title: Why Trump’s Boat Killings Would Be Hard to Prosecute
item.description: Even if critics who call President Trump’s boat attacks “murder” are right as a matter of law, it would not be easy to get the matter into a court.

item.title: French Magazine Acknowledges Breaching Prince William and Catherine’s Privacy
item.description: The couple had sued Paris Match for publishing paparazzi photos of them and their children on a ski vacation.

item.title: Syria’s Rocky Transition Brings New Waves of Displacement
item.description: More than 400,000 Syrians have been displaced in the year since the civil war ended, according to the United Nations, driven by a mix of sectarian violence, acts of revenge and property disputes.

item.title: French Police Arrest 5 More in Louvre Jewel Heist Investigation
item.description: The authorities have detained seven suspects in total but have not recovered the stolen jewels.

item.title: Far-Right Party Suffers Big Losses in Dutch Election as Centrists Surge
item.description: The progressive Democrats 66 gained seats and tied with the far-right party of Geert Wilders, which fell back sharply from a strong performance two years ago.

item.title: He Studied Why Some Female Birds Look Like Males
item.description: Jay Falk explored a fundamental question: How do genes give rise to different bodies? But without funding, “there’s not really a future here.”

item.title: Why a Cloud-Seeding Experiment to Fight Air Pollution in India Failed
item.description: Officials experimented with cloud seeding to try and reduce environmental pollutants as residents choke on filthy air.

item.title: China’s Pause on Rare Earth Controls: What to Know
item.description: China has suspended export controls announced this month, but was conspicuously silent about rules imposed earlier, which are snarling global supply chains.

item.title: Why the Price of Electricity Is Spiking Around the Country
item.description: Not all states have gotten hit equally hard. The reasons are complex.
